author.bio_html:

body:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a [user setting](/settings/profile) that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.
body_html:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a user setting that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.
title: Ruqqus 2.19 Update: Opt out of subscriptions by other users

parent.body_html: I've tried following someone before (before this opt-out feature was introduced), and their content didn't appear on my front page. Does the follow feature work for anyone else?

post.body:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a [user setting](/settings/profile) that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.

body:
Careful with this, it's precisely what allowed Digg to implode a decade ago, and led to Reddit's surge.

After a few years of allowing people to form organic circles of friends through the platform, where you could follow other users' posts, you ended up with a cabal of top-posters that religiously held the front page. The idea seemed great at first (as I'm sure it does here) but as soon as one of these Super-Users was compromised by outside paid influence (aka, MrBabyMan), it absolutely destroyed the whole platform overnight. 

Reddit allows you to make friends, and it allows those friends to direct message you to promote their posts, but never to the extent of Digg. Allowing users here to customize their page based on other user submissions will eventually lead to the exact same outcome that happened to Digg as soon as one of these power users is corrupted by money/media.

Please consider removing this entirely.

Allowing users here to customize their page based on other user submissions will eventually lead to the exact same outcome that happened to Digg as soon as one of these power users is corrupted by money/media.

Please consider removing this entirely.

body:
Sorry to bother you with this, @captainmeta4 , but I'm not sure of a better way to bring it up (I don't use discord), and didn't want to dirty your most recent post with a question/answer derail. Anyway, I can't get the "Block User" function to work anymore. It says it works when I try to use it, but it doesn't actually block the user, hide their posts from my feed, or stop them from commenting on my posts. This is only when I try to block someone new; people that have been blocked since before Sep 16th are staying blocked.  

If this is a known issue, my apologies.
body_html:
Sorry to bother you with this, @captainmeta4 , but I'm not sure of a better way to bring it up (I don't use discord), and didn't want to dirty your most recent post with a question/answer derail. Anyway, I can't get the "Block User" function to work anymore. It says it works when I try to use it, but it doesn't actually block the user, hide their posts from my feed, or stop them from commenting on my posts. This is only when I try to block someone new; people that have been blocked since before Sep 16th are staying blocked.

If this is a known issue, my apologies.

parent.body: @trumpvoter1
parent.body_html: @TrumpVoter1

post.body:
There's a feature that enables you to follow other users, adding their content to your personalized home feed. We've had feedback that this is too "stalky", allowing for easy downvote trolling.

We've added a [user setting](/settings/profile) that allows you to disable your profile subscriptions. This prevents other users from following you, and hides the follower count on your profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.

This should serve as a nice halfway between total publicity and locked down private profile.
